title: Bar on rails what can be determined about B

content.question: A metal conducting rod is free to move along horizontal conducting tracks connected at one end by a wire and a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The tracks are a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> apart. The rod is pulled to the right with force <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> so it moves at a constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. There is a uniform magnetic field of unknown magnitude <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> perpendicular to the plane of the page. Students measure <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following properties, if any, of the magnetic field can the students determine?

choices.label: The magnitude of the field can be determined, but not the direction because the direction of the current in the loop cannot be determined.
The direction of the field can be determined, but not the magnitude because the value of the current in the loop is not known.
Both the magnitude of the field and its direction can be determined because enough information is given.
Neither the magnitude nor the direction of the magnetic field can be determined.

content.answer: The magnitude of the field can be determined, but not the direction because the direction of the current in the loop cannot be determined.
